thread.title: Broker Watch: Westpac, McMillan Shakespeare, Crown, Billabong International
thread.title_full: Broker Watch: Westpac, McMillan Shakespeare, Crown, Billabong International | afr.com

author: Will Willitts
title: Broker Watch: Westpac, McMillan Shakespeare, Crown, Billabong International
text:
Deutsche Bank said Westpac's update showed 'financial metrics are broadly in line with our forecasts, outside of the ROE target which is more aggressive than our current expectations". Share on twitter by Will Willitts Deutsche Bank has a 'buy' recommendation on Westpac Banking Corporation (WBC) and a $34.65 target price.
In a note, Deutsche said WBC's cost targets were "broadly in line"and its ROE target "presents upside".
"Today's strategy update did not result in many surprises. WBC articulated its focus on service, and revealed an expanded investment spending program to deliver on this.
"While this additional spending (increase of ~20 per cent to $1.3bn p.a) is not a small amount, pleasingly this will be offset by a new productivity program in order to contain cost growth to 2-3 per cent p.a. in the near term, and to achieve a CTI ratio of sub-40 per cent within three years.
"Combined with this, management has also reiterated its ROE target of 15 per cent. These financial metrics are broadly in line with our forecasts, outside of the ROE target which is more aggressive than our current expectations. We maintain our Buy rating."
Citi has a 'neutral' recommendation on Billabong International (BBG) and a $0.70 target price.
"Billabong reported a 0.6 per cent decline in constant currency sales and 1 per cent growth in constant currency EBITDA for FY15. The results mark a point of stabilisation after a number of years in decline. However, working capital is still high, systems and sourcing needs an overhaul and currency headwinds exist for FY16e. We retain a Neutral rating with a target price of $0.70."
"We lowered our EPS by 0.4 cents to 1.8 cents in FY16e. Our operating earnings revisions are modest. Billabong is making good progress with its turnaround. However, margin gains will be gradual and a lot of change is still ahead in terms of systems. We expect some challenges in 1H16 given margin pressure in Australia and slower sales in the Americas."
 Credit Suisse has a "neutral" rating on Crown Limited (CWN) and a $12.60 target price.
The investment bank writes that "Crown's domestic casinos grew in the June half driven by strong mass market performance (Melbourne mass revenue +10.4 per cent vsp pcp, Perth +1.5 per cent). Costs were held tight. The outlook for VIP is positive as CWN has become more competitive, taking advantage of VIP tax adjustments in those jurisdictions.
"Macau continues to weigh on CWN's share price, despite a solid performance from domestic casinos and the implied value of those casinos screening as 'fair to cheap'. In late August, sell-side analysts cut MPEL (Melco Crown Entertainment) earnings for 2015 and 2016 coinciding with a drop in MPEL's share price. Although expectations are now more conservative, they still anticipate a strong EBITDA uplift with the first full year of Studio City (opening Oct 2015.)
"As recently as August, Macau gaming revenues were flattish on a sequential basis. We need growth to absorb new industry capacity. Given China's economic climate, we have not yet become confident that Studio City, a new casino, can deliver upon big market expectations".
Citi has a 'buy' recommendation on McMillan Shakespeare (MMS) and a $15.71 target price.
Citi said that "with the material regulatory volatility of FY14 behind them, MMS should continue to post solid organic growth numbers in both its remuneration services and asset finance businesses.
"MS's FY15 result was back to 'business as usual' and we expect FY16e to pleasantly surprise due to the annualisation of benefits from the Presidian and UFS acquisitions and a ~$2m catch-up from not having the 1H15 temporary contract suspension."
